titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Mary C. Rixford papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Natasha Porfirenko. Revised by Samira Bozorgi and Tess McCarthy, MLIS

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-05-11T11:08-0700

change.item: 2015: Amended finding aid to reflect items in folders; re-housed collection; created folder system to preseve some materials; updated finding aid to reflect additional changes, and re-checked inventory by Tess McCarthy, MLIS. 2012: Revised to update encoding by Samira Bozorgi.

did.unittitle: Mary C. Rixford papers
did.abstract: Collection relates to Allied propaganda, primarily British, during World War I, and to medical aspects of the war, especially activities of the American Red Cross

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research

Access to audiovisual materials requires at least two weeks advance notice. Audiovisual materials include sound recordings, video recordings, and motion picture film. Hoover staff will determine whether use copies of the materials requested can be made available. Some materials may not be accessible even with advance notice. Please contact the Hoover Institution Archives for further information.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Mary C. Rixford papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Collection relates to Allied propaganda, primarily British, during World War I, and to medical aspects of the war, especially activities of the American Red Cross.

Collection includes propaganda materials relating to military operations and home front conditions in many countries, especially Great Britain and Germany, during World War I. Pamphlets depict economic conditions in Germany during and immediately after World War I, especially food rationing, procurement of raw materials and war loan drives. Also includes German atrocities in France and Belgium, as well as work of the Committee on Alleged German Outrages.
Collection also includes pamphlets and monographs from Russian, Italian, Romanian, Turkish, Irish, and other sources.
Arranged by country, and therewith alphabetically by title. Some materials are placed in folders.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: World War I subject collection, 1914-2002, Hoover Institution Archives Payson J. Treat papers, 1855-1973, Hoover Institution Archives William C. Moore collection, 1914-1917, Hoover Institution Archives Price family papers, 1855-2004, Hoover Institution Archives

Evidence and Documents Laid before the Committee on Alleged German Outrages, Being on Appendix to the report of the Committee appointed by His Britannic Majesty's Government and presided over by the Right Hon. Viscount Bryce, O.M., Formerly British Ambassador to Washington. Contains details outrages on civil population in Belgium and France; the use of civilians as screen' offences against combatants; firing on hospitals, stretcher bearers, etc.; extracts from diaries and papers of German soldiers; proclamations by German Army authorities; some articles of the Hague convention concerning the laws and customs of war; facsimiles of papers found on German soldiers. Published by the Macmillan Company, New York for his Majesty's stationery Office, London,
The Fallacy of the German State Philosophy, George W. Crile, New York, Doubleday, Page and Company,

General Von Bissing's Testament: A Study in German Ideas, T. Fisher Unwin Ltd., London,
German Atrocities: from German Evidence, by Joseph Bédier, Professor at the Collège de France, translated by Bernard Harrison, Librairie Armand Colin, Paris,
